texts.kid-amateur-short: “God Save the Queen” is a famous song released in 1977 by the punk rock band Sex Pistols. It came out in the same year that Queen Elizabeth II celebrated 25 years on the throne. The song shocked many people because it criticized the monarchy and was even banned by the BBC. The cover showed a picture of the Queen with her eyes and mouth covered by bold words. At the same time, punk fashion was growing, and designer Vivienne Westwood helped make this new style visible through clothes and images.
texts.kid-amateur-long: “God Save the Queen” is a famous song released in 1977 by the punk rock band Sex Pistols. It came out in the same year that Queen Elizabeth II celebrated 25 years on the throne. The song shocked many people because it criticized the monarchy and was even banned by the BBC. The cover showed a picture of the Queen with her eyes and mouth covered by bold words. At the same time, punk fashion was growing, and designer Vivienne Westwood helped make this new style visible through clothes and images. Because the song was so different from traditional music, it became very popular with young people who felt angry or misunderstood. Punk music was loud, fast, and simple, and it talked about real problems instead of polite stories. The image on the cover became just as famous as the song. It looked rough and unfinished, breaking the rules of how records usually looked. Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren sold T-shirts in their London shop using the same image as the record cover. Wearing these shirts allowed young people to show that they did not agree with old rules and traditions. Through music and fashion together, “God Save the Queen” helped punk become a powerful way to express freedom, rebellion, and identity.
texts.kid-expert-short: Released in May 1977, “God Save the Queen” was the Sex Pistols’ second single and one of the most controversial songs in British history. Its lyrics criticized the monarchy during the Queen’s Silver Jubilee, leading to censorship and strong reactions from the media. The single’s artwork, created by Jamie Reid, altered a royal portrait using cut-out lettering, turning a symbol of authority into a sign of rebellion.
texts.kid-expert-long: Released in May 1977, “God Save the Queen” was the Sex Pistols’ second single and one of the most controversial songs in British history. Its lyrics criticized the monarchy during the Queen’s Silver Jubilee, leading to censorship and strong reactions from the media. The single’s artwork, created by Jamie Reid, altered a royal portrait using cut-out lettering, turning a symbol of authority into a sign of rebellion. This visual style was inspired by collage and protest art and was meant to look aggressive and unfinished. By changing the Queen’s image, the artwork questioned power and respect in a direct and shocking way. Vivienne Westwood used this same image on clothing sold in her shop, helping to bring punk ideas into everyday life. The clothes were not meant to be beautiful in a traditional sense but to make people think and react. Through this connection between music, art, and fashion, punk became more than a sound. It became a movement that allowed young people to challenge society and express their feelings openly.
texts.adult-amateur-short: “God Save the Queen” is a key 1977 punk single by the Sex Pistols, released during Queen Elizabeth II’s Silver Jubilee. Its direct attack on the monarchy caused widespread controversy and resulted in broadcast bans. The cover artwork, designed by Jamie Reid, transformed an official royal portrait into a provocative punk image. Vivienne Westwood’s adoption of this imagery in fashion linked the single to the visual identity of punk culture.
texts.adult-amateur-long: “God Save the Queen” is a key 1977 punk single by the Sex Pistols, released during Queen Elizabeth II’s Silver Jubilee. Its direct attack on the monarchy caused widespread controversy and resulted in broadcast bans. The cover artwork, designed by Jamie Reid, transformed an official royal portrait into a provocative punk image. Vivienne Westwood’s adoption of this imagery in fashion linked the single to the visual identity of punk culture. This connection between music and imagery helped the single reach far beyond record stores. Despite censorship, the song became extremely popular and is often remembered as the sound of a generation rejecting established authority. Reid’s graphic design broke with traditional record sleeves by using ransom-note typography and visual disruption, reinforcing the song’s confrontational message. Westwood, working closely with Malcolm McLaren, brought this same aesthetic into clothing through T-shirts sold in their boutique. These garments turned punk graphics into everyday statements, allowing wearers to publicly align themselves with anti-establishment values. Together, the song and its imagery show how punk used multiple creative fields to communicate a shared cultural message.
texts.adult-expert-short: “God Save the Queen” represents a crucial convergence of sound, graphic design, and fashion within punk culture. The single deploys visual and lyrical provocation to undermine institutional authority, particularly through the deliberate defacement of royal imagery. Vivienne Westwood’s engagement with this aesthetic demonstrates how punk’s visual language extended beyond music into design practice.
texts.adult-expert-long: “God Save the Queen” represents a crucial convergence of sound, graphic design, and fashion within punk culture. The single deploys visual and lyrical provocation to undermine institutional authority, particularly through the deliberate defacement of royal imagery. Vivienne Westwood’s engagement with this aesthetic demonstrates how punk’s visual language extended beyond music into design practice. Westwood’s translation of the single’s graphic language into fashion materialized most clearly in the “God Save the Queen” T-shirt, produced and sold in her boutique with Malcolm McLaren in 1977. The garment adopted Jamie Reid’s defaced royal portrait through screen-printing techniques that emphasized flatness, visual aggression, and immediacy rather than refinement. The T-shirt itself, a traditionally utilitarian and mass-produced item, was deliberately recontextualized as a political surface. Westwood exploited its associations with youth culture and everyday wear, using it as a canvas for dissent. Distressed finishes, provocative slogans, and confrontational iconography rejected conventional notions of taste, craftsmanship, and luxury that dominated British fashion at the time. This approach aligned with Westwood’s broader punk methodology, which privileged anti-construction, symbolic abrasion, and the exposure of process over tailored perfection. Garments were not designed to flatter the body or conform to established silhouettes but to communicate attitude, ideology, and resistance. By integrating Reid’s graphic détournement into wearable form, Westwood collapsed the boundaries between record sleeve, protest poster, and fashion object. The “God Save the Queen” T-shirt thus became a foundational example of fashion as visual rhetoric, positioning clothing as an active participant in punk’s challenge to cultural authority and redefining design practice as an explicitly political act.

texts.kid-amateur-short: The Westwood MacAndreas tartan is a special colorful check pattern made by Vivienne Westwood in 1993. It looks like the old Scottish tartans, but Vivienne gave it a fun, modern twist. She named it MacAndreas after her husband, Andreas Kronthaler. Tartans are made of criss‑crossed stripes, like a puzzle of colors that can be used on skirts, jackets, and scarves. Vivienne used her tartan on lots of clothes to make them look bold, exciting, and a little bit naughty — just like punk fashion!

It looks like the old Scottish tartans, but Vivienne gave it a fun, modern twist. She named it MacAndreas after her husband, Andreas Kronthaler. Tartans are made of criss‑crossed stripes, like a puzzle of colors that can be used on skirts, jackets, and scarves. Vivienne used her tartan on lots of clothes to make them look bold, exciting, and a little bit naughty — just like punk fashion! Vivienne wanted to take something old and make it new and exciting. She worked with expert Scottish weavers to create her very own tartan. The MacAndreas tartan became one of the special patterns everyone remembered from Vivienne’s shows. It showed that old, traditional things could be turned into something cool, bold, and full of personality.

In her Anglomania AW 1993/94 collection, she applied the tartan to tailored jackets, asymmetric skirts, and layered ensembles, often contrasting it with unexpected fabrics or cuts. Its repeated presence in subsequent collections reinforced its status as a signature motif. By integrating a historical Scottish textile into garments that played with proportion, structure, and layering, Westwood showed how a designer could reinterpret heritage with a bold, contemporary eye. The tartan’s use in multiple runway collections made it both a visual anchor and a symbol of her punk-influenced design philosophy, blending tradition with rebellion.

By juxtaposing the tartan with contrasting fabrics and unconventional cuts, Westwood destabilized expectations of symmetry, polish, and historical fidelity, asserting designer authorship over both pattern and garment structure. Through its repeated presence on the runway, the MacAndreas tartan became a signature emblem of Westwood’s design philosophy, exemplifying how a heritage textile can be elevated to a political and stylistic statement within fashion, blending Scottish tradition, punk ethos, and couture-level construction.

texts.kid-amateur-short: The “God Save the Queen” top is a famous T-shirt made by Vivienne Westwood with her partner Malcolm McLarenin the late 1970s. It has a big picture on the front that shows Queen Elizabeth II with a safety pin on her face, making it look wild and rebellious, just like punk music and fashion were back then. The design comes from the artwork used on the Sex Pistols record “God Save the Queen,” and it helped make this shirt one of the most famous punk clothes ever. People wore it to show they questioned old rules and liked bold, different styles.

texts.adult-amateur-short: The God Save the Queen top is a seminal punk T-shirt designed by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren in the late 1970s, most notably sold through their Seditionaries boutique in London. Its graphic, based on Jamie Reid’s lithography for the Sex Pistols God Save the Queen, intentionally subverts established imagery of monarchy to produce a confrontational visual statement. This top became an emblem of early British punk fashion, blending music, visual art, and clothing into a single provocative cultural artefact.
texts.adult-amateur-long: The God Save the Queen top is a seminal punk T-shirt designed by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren in the late 1970s, most notably sold through their Seditionaries boutique in London. Its graphic, based on Jamie Reid’s lithography for the Sex Pistols God Save the Queen, intentionally subverts established imagery of monarchy to produce a confrontational visual statement. This top became an emblem of early British punk fashion, blending music, visual art, and clothing into a single provocative cultural artefact. The God Save the Queen top occupies a central place in the history of punk design as one of the earliest and most influential examples of fashion’s engagement with subculture and political critique. Created in the late 1970s by Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren, the shirt was sold at Seditionaries, their boutique on King’s Road, a crucible for punk aesthetics, cultural exchange, and anti-establishment design experimentation. The graphic derives directly from Jamie Reid’s lithographic treatment for the Sex Pistols’ God Save the Queen single, a defaced portrait of Queen Elizabeth II that became synonymous with punk’s challenge to national authority and popular imagery. By transposing this visual onto cotton knitwear, Westwood transformed political provocation into wearable iconography. The top’s intentional roughness, including raw seams, visible stitching, and distressed surfaces, aligned it with punk’s broader rejection of polished fashion norms and its embrace of anti-fashion gestures that foregrounded material disruption over conventional refinement. This design not only articulated punk’s visual language in garment form but also helped establish a template for how fashion could engage directly with music, youth identity, and visual culture, making the T-shirt itself a potent cultural artefact that echoed across subsequent decades of style and performance art.
texts.adult-expert-short: The God Save the Queen top exemplifies cross-disciplinary design strategies at the intersection of fashion, graphic art, and subcultural expression. Its appropriation of Jamie Reid’s subversive lithography onto cotton knitwear illustrates Vivienne Westwood’s early exploration of design as visual critique, where surface and structure are deployed to challenge established cultural narratives.
texts.adult-expert-long: The God Save the Queen top exemplifies cross-disciplinary design strategies at the intersection of fashion, graphic art, and subcultural expression. Its appropriation of Jamie Reid’s subversive lithography onto cotton knitwear illustrates Vivienne Westwood’s early exploration of design as visual critique, where surface and structure are deployed to challenge established cultural narratives. The God Save the Queen top is a defining artifact in the evolution of punk fashion as a disciplined design practice, in which clothing becomes an active medium of cultural critique rather than passive ornamentation. Emerging from the milieu of the Seditionaries boutique circa 1976–1977, it represents a deliberate appropriation of Jamie Reid’s graphic lexicon, a defaced royal portrait interwoven with provocative text, as a surface strategy applied to knitwear. This shirt’s design logic reflects Westwood’s early interrogation of fashion’s role in transmitting ideology: the deliberate visibility of seams and raw edges speaks to a constructional aesthetic that privileges disruption and anti-aesthetic rhetoric over the polished silhouettes typical of mainstream collections of the era. Such techniques prefigure later punk-influenced looks on runway and in couture, where the boundaries between garment and graphic artifact blur. Within the context of late 1970s London, God Save the Queen operated not merely as apparel but as a mobile graphic statement, worn by musicians, performers, and youth culture figures who foregrounded resistance through fashion. Its presence in key institutional collections today underscores its significance as an early exemplar of fashion’s capacity to engage with political and cultural narratives.

historical.title: Chronicles of Fashion
historical.description: Chronicles of Fashion unfolds as a chronological narrative that situates Vivienne Westwood’s work within a broader cultural and historical continuum. The collection begins with the French artistic and historical references that inspired her vision and then progresses through her most emblematic punk designs, to conclude with her presence in contemporary media and popular culture, from Sex & The City and Nana to significant examples of her public activism. Collectively, these works trace not only the evolution of a designer, but the establishment of an enduring cultural legacy.

made-by.title: Made by Vivienne
made-by.description: Made by Vivienne is a deep dive into the creative genius of Dame Vivienne Westwood, presenting only the works she personally conceived and brought into being. From the raw energy of punk rebellion to refined tailoring and historical reinterpretation, each item embodies her revolutionary approach to fashion, transforming traditional forms such as the corset and Scottish tartan into symbols of power and innovation. Beyond their aesthetic impact, these works also carry her enduring commitment to activism, integrating social and environmental protest into the very fabric of design. Together, they reveal a vision defined not just by garments, but by the principles and audacity that make every object unmistakably Made by Vivienne.

past-future.title: Past and Future
past-future.description: Past and Future traces the interplay of references that shaped Vivienne Westwood’s distinctive vision, bringing together the works that informed her creativity, the designs that emerged from those influences, and the cultural echoes her style continues to generate. Starting with the historical and artistic references that nourished her imagination, the collection moves into the garments and accessories that exemplify her transformative approach to tradition, before closing with the many afterlives of her designs in contemporary media and popular culture, from the iconic wedding gown worn by Carrie Bradshaw in Sex and the City to the striking appearances of Westwood’s creations in Nana, alongside records that witness her public activism and irreverence. Overall, the collection aims at revealing the continuous exchange between past reference and future expression within Westwood’s creative universe.
